terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Alberta mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Alberta event. Mountainous terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: The Range is a regional event in Alberta‚Äîmountainous terrain with significant elevation. The Alberta mountains are scenic and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Alberta mountain gravel race. Worth it for Canadian riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Canada‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're international‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Canadian terrain: Ghost of the Gravel.

logistics.food: Alberta has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping:
camping move-in (3:00-9:00 PM), and packet pickup (6:00-8:00 PM)
- Saturday: Staggered starts for different distances (6:45 AM f

logistics.explanation: Calgary airport then 90-minute drive to Claresholm isn't convenient. Limited lodging options in a town of 3800 people means booking early or camping at Centennial Park. Start/finish at the same location helps, but small-town infrastructure shows its limits quickly.

length.explanation: The Range delivers 122km with 1,606m elevation gain, while The Frontier stretches to 211km with 3,000m elevation. Chip timing tracks overall rankings plus a Range Sector Challenge - a demanding 3km segment near the finish when legs are already worked.

technicality.explanation: Two natural creek crossings through Burton's Burke Creek Ranch (established 1890) plus single truss bridges create technical moments. The route includes 2-track ranch roads, 'The Wall' climb, and 'the incredible Skyline road' - described as one of Alberta's best kept secrets. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The classic Range route climbs 1,606 meters over 122km through the Porcupine hills, while The Frontier tackles 3,000m over 211km. The terrain includes 'The Wall' and varied ecosystems from grasslands to dense forest with Rocky Mountain views. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Mid-July in southern Alberta typically runs 70-85¬∞F with afternoon thunderstorm potential. Standard prairie weather - manageable without the furnace heat of Kansas summer gravel or hypothermia risk of early season mountain races. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Claresholm sits around 3000 feet in the Alberta foothills. High enough that sea-level lungs might notice after 60 miles, low enough that altitude won't be the limiting factor for most riders tackling The Range's demanding terrain.

adventure.explanation: Private ranch access through Burke Creek Ranch opens territory 'typically off-limits to the public.' The route traverses open grasslands, dense Porcupine hills forest, and ranch roads with sweeping Rocky Mountain views that riders can't access any other day.

prestige.explanation: TransRockies President Aaron McConnell calls The Range 'an iconic event that aligns perfectly with what we do.' Founded in 2020, it joined the TransRockies Race Series in 2024 and now earns points toward the Gravel Earth Series ranking.

race_quality.explanation: Over 50 directional signs mark the course with chip timing for overall rankings. Three aid stations provide support, plus bike mechanics and sweepers. The Range Sector Challenge adds tactical racing near the finish when fatigue peaks.

experience.explanation: Event founder Garth Stotts describes 'a celebration of Alberta's unique natural ecosystems where sustainable ranching practices have preserved this often-overlooked natural gem.' ChillVille beer garden runs 11 AM-7 PM at the Centennial Park finish.

community.explanation: Capped at 500 riders with camping available at Centennial Park creates weekend atmosphere. Friday night packet pickup, Saturday staggered starts, and full day beer garden at ChillVille. Founded during 2020 pandemic, it 'quickly pedaled into cyclists' hearts.'

field_depth.explanation: 2025 results show modest fields: The Rustler drew 125 starters with DNF rates around 25-29%. TransRockies partnership aims to elevate the event internationally, but current field sizes reflect regional Alberta gravel scene rather than elite depth. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: The Rodeo 60km launch pricing at $139 includes custom bike plate, event t-shirt, food/beverage wristband, and $100 discount for Rough Rider event. Exclusive ranch access and three aid stations justify TransRockies-level pricing for weekend adventure.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150 CAD. Claresholm lodging options include Best Seven Inn, Lazy J Motel, and Centennial Park camping. Flying into Calgary adds 90-minute drive south plus car rental costs. Small Alberta town keeps lodging basic but affordable compared to destination resort pricing. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: The Range 2022 - Gravel Cycling Classic!
videos.description: The Range Gravel Race and Ride from July 23, 2022! The Range is the premier gravel cycling event in Alberta. 128 km - 3 creeks - Private Roads - Steep Climbs - Stunning Scenery - 100% Gravel
videos.curation_reason: Official race footage with good view count showcasing the full 128km course highlights.

videos.title: The Range Race and Event - 2021 by The Gravel Experience
videos.description: The Range is an Epic Gravel Cycling Event and Race in SW Alberta. The course weaves through the hills on public and private ranch roads providing a premier gravel cycling experience.

videos.title: Riding The Range: The Rustler, July 20, 2024
videos.description:
I suspect people enter gravel bike races for more reasons than racing, or winning. This video shares my experience as I tied a number onto my gravel bike, for my first ever organized bike race, The Rustler, the intermediate distance within The Range, a gravel bike race presented by thegravelexperience.com We rolled over public gravel roads, and private ranch land, in the beautiful foothills of Southern Alberta, Canada. Sometimes the gravel experience is about what we might find on the trail.

GoPro footage, iPhone video, some still images by Christine Pedersen.
Many of the still images are used with the kind permission of race photographer Cody  Shimizu https://www.codyshimizu.com/the-range-2024?ct=2
üôè So many thanks to my riding mate--Calgary author Barb Howard, the Town of Claresholm, Burke Creek Ranch https://burkecreekranch.com , and the incredible event volunteers and course marshals: hope to see you next year‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•

we knew that in the afternoon it was

fun a good
day it was a pretty special feeling
going off down that gravel I wasn't
nervous so much as super excited for a
big day out on the bike
we were absolutely loaded with food and
water prepared to be self-sufficient but
knowing we had an aid station at our
turnaround
Point heading out Barb and I had the
option of riding either the 60 km Rodeo
ride or if we felt good when we got to a
junction way up the road we could turn
left and carry on for the full rustler
distance but we really wanted to ride
the
rustler oh that's a beautiful shot
straight down the road all the bikes
laned
out Barb's got a lot of racing
experience behind her and we knew that
we could do the distance with we trained
hard for it all spring but we weren't
there to win prizes we were there for a
big day out riding our bikes in
beautiful countryside and having a
brilliant time on this absolutely
incredible gravel course it was in
perfect
condition my prep over the long cold
Calgary Winter was to ride on zwift
without door riding as soon as the ice
was gone from the paths and I added
weights and pilates and some yogur in
front of the T and it's all on straa so
it all
counts as soon as we could get outside
Barb and I rode as much gravel around
Calgary as possible we have a couple of
favorite rides that we would head to and
we started up in the distance getting in
some very hot 4-Hour
rides when dinosaurs rule the
Earth I had this almost romantic Vision
that this is a landscape where dinosaurs
had died their bodies buried now deep in
the coolies
Alberta is very fossil rich and the

ancient I think the training prepared me
very well to do this though of course I
wish I could have gone faster
sh really down
I also knew the sort of pace I thought I
could aim for working for my heart rate
zones anticipating how my body would
feel and I came up with a Target time I

1/2 hours maximum
it was a really hot day there had been
plans earlier in the week to shorten the

on Barb and I had talked beforehand

shorter Rodeo or would we ride the
rustler as we'd hoped coming up to our
Junction I saw Bobb look back at me turn
her bike left and I knew at that point
she felt good and she was committed to
the rustler I was thrilled
bir cre R 8 Miles that's where we're
going most of the race was ridden over
public gravel roads they were really
quiet and the traffic was mainly

by riding the rustler we were able to

of the
year and here we go this is our prize
down this super fast Hill onto the ranch
and there it all is stretching out in

I dreamed about all of this for a couple
of years really since I first learned
about this race of being out here in

riding on this
land there are Riders belting back past

range course yep green badge that person
had ridden the range and they were
really
moving orange badge like mine they're
riding the rustler many of the bikes
were like mine using a 2 by setup and
most people had a couple of water
bottles and a hydration pack
I was drinking about 3/4 of a liter per
hour eating bars and homemade rice cakes
on the way out and boy were they good
really kept the furnace
stoked I was so glad I had this gorgeous
downhill all to myself the valley
scenery was just opening up around me
this was a feature that I was really
looking forward to the river crossing we
only had one wet river crossing the
other one was dry here comes the
footbath I was heading for my exit point
but the front wheel got knocked off
course by a rock right at the
edge I love saying hey bells in fields
it makes me happy I grew up in the
country and I rode land like this on my
pony There's real joy in seeing that
feed being prepared for the winter it
makes me think of all the farmers I've
ever known how hard they worked and just
how important the work
is the fabulous volunteers who looked
after us are mostly experienced bike
riders too
they knew exactly what to do Coke chips
and dipping our bike helmets into ice
water it was so
good this is the wall it's a real Beast
even many of the really good cyclists
were going to be walking it it's a
kilometer long and it maxes out at
177% just like that on the way back
that was kind of the beauty of doing the
rustler course for me the intermediate
distance we didn't have to face the wall
in that
heat having slogged through 5 hours of
riding in what felt like 34 Cel it might
sound strange to say I would love to do
it again and I would love to ride the
long course to challenge myself going
over the wall when I met up with Barb at
the a station I was pretty thrilled when
she told me we'd actually made it there
before the posted cut off time in order
to take the long
course I hadn't even thought about that
as a girl it was a pretty sweet surprise
the reality though is that the extra 40
km loop on the long course is really
tough and there's another thousand M of
climbing to
do
a now we
climb so much of challenging myself to
ride this event was about learning what
my body is capable of now and part of
learning to trust it again after breast
cancer
it was so great descending on my Grizzle
it felt so shooted as if it knew the way
it handled beautifully super responsive
and comfortable I absolutely love that
bike it was set up tubeless with 45 mil
pelli centur H Tires I think those tires
were perfect for that course in that
condition and for other bike nerds the
tire pressures were 30 PSI at the rear
and 29 at the front and my chain was
waxed obviously
the climb out of the ranch averaged
around 11% and I knew I should keep
something back for that it actually went
surprisingly well I was up it before I
knew it puffing but I stuck to my plan
of not going too deep into the red
the gravel roads were in such great
shape they were so fast rolling I think
G starts the organizer called it hero
gravel I like
that the trans Rockies truck passed us
quite a few times during the day they
did an excellent job there were a lot of
vehicles going backwards and forwards
checking on the course and the Riders
making sure there weren't serious
Mechanicals or people in difficulty the
ride felt so well supported
on the way back and getting passed by
Speedy Riders they've been out on the
long course and are going like hell and
they're going to get back way before me
but you know what I didn't care I was
just so happy to be out
there I couldn't call it racing because
it was really just about being out there
and that's why I chose to stop and take
some
video it's almost like I woke up about
15 km from the finish and just had this
feeling of it's nearly over and I didn't
want it to be over
Crossing that line was incredibly
emotional I was so joyful I'd had a
little moment when I let out a sort of
Primal whale all on my own just out of
sheer Joy somewhere around 5 Corners
from the end when I realized oh my god
I've nearly done it I'm actually here I
trained I committed and I did
it is this going to
end I was pretty glad to get back and
share some hugs to congratulate Bobb for
being speedier than me and have a really
long drink and start eating all the
snacks but I still didn't want it to be
over I loved it I'm so grateful to have
done it I'm so thankful for all the
support that got me here for the amazing
organization at the event for the
privilege of taking
part and really just for being alive the
opportunity to be out there there on the
land living out all the preparation and
learning more about how to nurture
myself it was an incredible experience
and it was over far too
fast you don't have to make it
we nothing's going to stop you just
being the way you
are nothing's going to change the way
never come
down never come
down never come down
videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person race recap with detailed personal experience and course insights from The Rustler distance.

videos.title: The Range - Non Event Ride in 2020
videos.description:
Stunning scenery and the Epic Experience of The Range. 

This is a gravel cycling event in the beautiful southwest Alberta. 

A summer adventure celebrating gravel cycling at its peak. 

Route Highlights:
-Multiple creek crossings
-Private Roads
-Historic Ranches
-Steep Climbs
-4 varied eco-systems
-All types of Gravels

Music licensed to The Gravel Experience from Premiumbeat.com

videos.title: THE RUSTLER ( THE RANGE ) GRAVEL RACE VLOG BY @DINGDONGTV17

quotes.text: It was a pretty special feeling going off down that gravel. I wasn't nervous so much as super excited for a big day out on the bike. We were absolutely loaded with food and water prepared to be self-sufficient but knowing we had an aid station at our turnaround point.
We were there for a big day out riding our bikes in beautiful countryside and having a brilliant time on this absolutely incredible gravel course. It was in perfect condition.

When dinosaurs ruled the Earth I had this almost romantic vision that this is a landscape where dinosaurs had died, their bodies buried now deep in the coulees. Alberta is very fossil rich and the shape of the land feels ancient.

key_challenges.name: Junction Decision Point
key_challenges.description: Riders must choose between the 60km Rodeo ride or turning left to continue for the full rustler distance. Decision point impacts race strategy especially on hot days.

key_challenges.name: Burke Creek Ranch
key_challenges.description: Private road onto working ranch accessible only on race day, features super fast downhill section onto the ranch property.

terrain_notes.text: Gravel course was in perfect condition with public gravel roads that are really quiet with mainly marshalling vehicles for traffic.
Landscape feels ancient and fossil-rich with dinosaur burial sites deep in the coulees, stretching out pristine ranch views.

race_day_tips.text: If not used to riding in a pack, give yourself more space as the first part goes really fast.
Come prepared to be self-sufficient with food and water, though there is an aid station at the turnaround point.
Work from heart rate zones and anticipate how your body will feel to set realistic target times.

additional_quotes.text: Race day a lovely sunny morning around 20 Celsius, we knew that in the afternoon it was going to be in the mid-30s. The ride started at 8:00 so we would be back before the real heat of the day kicked in.

My prep over the long cold Calgary Winter was to ride on zwift, without door riding as soon as the ice was gone from the paths and I added weights and pilates and some yoga, and it's all on strava so it all counts.

rider_intel.search_text: The Range rustler is an 86km gravel race in Alberta featuring mostly public gravel roads in perfect condition with quiet traffic. Key features include a decision junction where riders choose between 60km Rodeo or full rustler distance, and exclusive access to Burke Creek Ranch via private road with fast downhill section. Race starts at 8am in 20C temperatures before afternoon heat reaches mid-30s. Course has one aid station at turnaround point. Terrain feels ancient and fossil-rich through Alberta coulees. Early pace goes really fast requiring pack riding skills. Riders should come self-sufficient with food and water and plan around hot afternoon conditions.

Aerial view of gravel road crossing stream with cyclists navigating water crossing through lush green valley - The Range - Alberta, Canada
